metadata.sermon_title: Why Jesus Had to Die: Because of What He Did!
metadata.sermon_start_end: We know in Lent how the story goes. It was an unequal contest between Jesus and his timid disciples and the power of the Roman Empire abetted by some Jews who had signed on with the empire. It was an unequal contest, and it ended in his execution. [...] This is a very short story; but it is our story and it concerns us. It is the script of our life. We need only to decide the role in which we are cast. It is our script on the way to the Friday execution.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon stays close to the narrative structure of Mark 3:1-6. It identifies the specific tension of the Sabbath protocol. However, it misses the 'nowhere else' factor by treating the Sabbath conflict as a generic example of 'protocol' rather than the unique theological revelation of the Son of Man as Lord of the Sabbath.
quotes: The drama of this quick encounter features three actors
Mark is terse as all three characters are in play
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus on why the Sabbath specifically—as God’s own rest—is the site of this conflict, rather than treating it as a general sociological 'protocol'.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The exegesis is largely narrative-descriptive. While it correctly identifies the Pharisees and Herodians, it lacks depth in the Greek nuances or the specific Second Temple theological weight of the Sabbath. It leans more on sociological imagination (agricultural accidents) than rigorous historical-theological exegesis.
quotes: The synagogue is the meeting place for pious Jews
maybe caught in a corn-picker or some other agricultural equipment
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the specific theological meaning of 'hardness of heart' (porosis) in the context of Israel's covenant history.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete regarding racial and social stratification, which Dekker values. However, it risks becoming a general lecture on social justice rather than a specific application of the Word of God to the spiritual state of the hearer.
quotes: racial protocols, for example, that are softer than they used to be
who gets to vote, who gets credit at what rate
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Connect the social 'protocols' more directly to the hearer's own 'misery' before God, rather than just as a societal critique.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon successfully moves back and forth between the text and the contemporary city. It avoids the 'block' structure (first exegesis, then application), drawing the hearer into the synagogue scene as a contemporary reality.
quotes: Jesus in fact says to the guardians of the protocols: Look at his injury!
This city knows about such protocols
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Ensure the 'present of revelation' is felt more as God speaking now, rather than just a dramatic reenactment.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Misery is present in the form of 'hard-heartedness' and 'disability.' Redemption is seen in the 'messianic juices of restoration.' However, gratitude (the life of the justified) is almost entirely absent, replaced by a call to 'decide the role.'
quotes: They couldn’t make that trade-off because they were hard-hearted.
His hand was restored. [...] It sounds like a resurrection!
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Develop the 'gratitude' section: what does the life of the restored man look like after the Sabbath?

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon mentions the 'death that will happen' and the 'destruction' of Jesus, but it frames the 'two ways' as a choice of 'roles' in a play rather than an ultimate destination before God. The seriousness of being 'lost' is softened into social exclusion.
quotes: We need only to decide the role in which we are cast.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the 'eternal loss' or the gravity of rejecting the Messiah more sharply; the choice is not just theatrical but existential.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the actor, but he is portrayed primarily as a victim of 'established authority' or a 'messianic' healer. His divinity (Two Natures) is not explicit. Grace is present in the healing, but the sermon ends on human decision ('decide the role') rather than the finished work of Christ.
quotes: Jesus has to be executed because of what he did.
the messianic juices of restoration were released.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Shift the telos from the hearer's 'role' to Christ's objective victory over the 'protocols' of sin and death.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1,150 words, the sermon lasts about 11-12 minutes. According to Thesis 8, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for true homiletical depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the theological exposition of the Sabbath and the nature of Christ's authority to reach the 20-minute threshold.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short primarily on length and the gravity of the 'two ways.' It prioritizes a sociological-political application over a robust dogmatic foundation. While the narrative movement is effective, it lacks the 'breadth' Dekker demands for depth and ends on a moralistic note of human choice rather than the sustaining grace of the 'One Lord.'
strengths: Effective interwoven structure of text and contemporary context.
Concrete application to local social 'protocols' (racial and economic).
Strong narrative engagement with the silence and hardness of the Pharisees.
weaknesses: Insufficient length (approx. 11 minutes) prevents theological depth.
Weak Christology; Jesus is more a social agitator than the Incarnate Word.
The 'two ways' are reduced to choosing a role in a drama rather than an ultimate life-or-death destination.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an adequate speech with strong social relevance, but it is not yet a 'sermon' in the full sense of Dekker’s theses due to its brevity and the lack of a clear dogmatic telos in Christ.
